quote: Just set them on the bar.
Morn -- no touching.
You know what this is?       Three cases of syrup of squill.
I love syrup of squill on my   groatcakes. But I haven't seen   a jar in over a year.
No one has.
Does that mean the drought on   Balancar's over?
There never was a drought on    Balancar. It was all a ploy by    their Agricultural Consortium.    They've been stockpiling squill    so they could drive the price up.
That's dishonest.

I couldn't agree more. You see,    I once did some business with the    nephew of the cousin of the    stepsister of a friend of the    secretary to the Consortium's    chief accountant...    (stopping, double-    checking with himself)    Nephew, cousin, stepsister,    friend... yeah, that's right. And    he told me, in passing, that the    accountant had bought himself a    pair of very nice Ferengi rain    slippers.
If there was a drought, he    wouldn't need rain slippers.

My thoughts exactly.        So I set up a meeting with this    accountant and told him that he    either provide me with a shipment    of syrup, or I'd expose their    deception to the entire quadrant.    Tomorrow morning, we're having a    special on groatcakes, topped with    syrup of squill -- that is, for    everyone who can afford it.

What are you standing around for? Get    these crates in the storeroom -- this    stuff is worth its weight in latinum.        Which reminds me of another little    economic exploit of mine...        It happened, oh, I'd say... eleven,    twelve years ago, shortly before I    arrived here...
Dax, Julian -- you're back! I was    so worried.
I told you it was going to be okay.
Then why all the secrecy about your    mission?
Because we aren't supposed to talk    about it.
But now it's okay. The mission's    over, we've been debriefed.        We took the Defiant behind enemy    lines.
We're the first reconnaissance   mission into Cardassian space since   the Dominion's retreat.
The first to make it back, anyway.
And if that's not a reason to    celebrate, then I don't know what    is...
Three synthales.
Coming right up.
Something wrong, Quark?
They're not just Starfleet    officers -- they're heroes. And    let's face it, Quark, there's    nothing heroic about earning    profit.
There is on Ferenginar.
We're not on Ferenginar.
The Nagus... calling me -- now?         He must've found out about the    squill... I'll have to send him    a jar -- better make it a dozen.    He loves squill.
There you are. I've been looking    all over the station for you.
Well, you found me.         Now you go hide and I'll search    for you.
Rom, brace yourself. I have bad    news. Our mother's been taken    prisoner by the Dominion.
Moogie -- a prisoner?
It gets worse.
The Nagus wants me to rescue her.
You? Rescue Moogie? From the   Dominion?    (as the implications     sink in)   Uh-oh.
"Uh-oh" is right.
So how do you plan on rescuing    Moogie?
You mean how do we plan on    rescuing Moogie.
I don't recall you saying the    Nagus wanted me to go along.
Maybe he doesn't -- but I do.    Besides, Ishka is your mother, too.
And I love her. But I can't go    with you. I'm a married man. I    have responsibilities. And my    responsibilities don't want me to    die.
I don't want to die either. So    let's just concentrate on the    reward the Nagus is offering.
Reward?
Fifty bars of gold-pressed latinum.
Fifty bars!
Ow.
Which I'm willing to share with you.
An even split?
Absolutely. Thirty bars for me    and twenty for you.
That's not even.
It is when you include my finder's fee.
Right.
There's one thing I still don't    understand. How did the Dominion    get a hold of Moogie?
They captured the transport ship    she was on.
But she's a female -- they're    forbidden to travel off of    Ferenginar.
Moogie's an exception. The Nagus    gave her special dispensation to    travel to Vulcan for her operation.
What operation?
She wanted to have her ears raised.
I had no idea...
That she was so vain?
That the Nagus could be so    generous.        But why is he being so good to    Moogie?
Brother, there's something I need    to tell you...
You mean that ten bars of latinum    is an overly generous finder's    fee? I already know that.
It's about the Nagus and Moogie.
What about them?
They're lovers.
Noooo.
It's been going on for over a year.
Noooo.
She's his secret financial   advisor -- she helps him run the   entire Ferengi Alliance.
Noooo.
Would you stop saying that.
Can I help you, gentlemen?
I was following you.
We must've taken a wrong turn.
Looks that way.
Much better.
You know, brother... I've been    thinking. We can't rescue Moogie    from a Dominion internment    center -- not alone anyway.
You're right. We're going to need    help.
We could put together a commando   team. Gather the toughest    mercenaries we can find...    Nausicaans, Breen, Klingons.
We don't need Nausicaans -- or    Breen or Klingons.
Hew-mons?
We'll just use Ferengi.
Then we'll all die.
No we won't. Ferengi can be just    as tough as Klingons.
They can?
Of course they can -- they just    need the opportunity, the    training, and a couple of bars of    latinum as incentive.
Coming out of my share, I suppose.
No, we'll split the reward with    whoever joins us. All twenty bars    of it.
But the Nagus offered fifty.
As far as anyone else is    concerned, he said twenty.
Twenty it is then.
Now the question is, who's our    first recruit?
Not me.
scene: 12   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL - CLOSE ON NOG

quote: But Nog, Moogie needs you!
scene: 12   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL - CLOSE ON NOG

quote: Not to mention your Nagus.
scene: 12   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL - CLOSE ON NOG

quote: They need you -- we need you. Say    you'll join us.
scene: 12   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL - CLOSE ON NOG

quote: Please.
scene: 12   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL - CLOSE ON NOG

quote: I'm a Starfleet Officer. I can't    go running off with you on some    half-baked rescue mission. I have    duties to perform.
scene: 12   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL - CLOSE ON NOG

quote: But you know how to fire a phaser.
scene: 12   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL - CLOSE ON NOG

quote: Forget it, Rom. Don't beg.        Too bad, though. We were going    to make you strategic operations    officer.
scene: 12   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL - CLOSE ON NOG

quote: You mean like Commander Worf?
scene: 12   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL - CLOSE ON NOG

quote: Exactly like Commander Worf.        Think of it, Nog -- you'll devise    the tactics... come up with a plan    of action.
scene: 12   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL - CLOSE ON NOG

quote: You can be the team's drill    instructor. Put us through our    paces! Prepare us for combat!
scene: 12   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL - CLOSE ON NOG

quote: Turn us into soldiers.
scene: 12   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL - CLOSE ON NOG

quote: That's a big job.
scene: 12   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL - CLOSE ON NOG

quote: (putting a hand on Nog's     shoulder)    That's why we need you.
scene: 12   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL - CLOSE ON NOG

quote: How big is the team?
scene: 12   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL - CLOSE ON NOG

quote: Right now...
scene: 12   INT. PROMENADE - SECOND LEVEL - CLOSE ON NOG

quote: Now remember, Leck is not your    typical Ferengi. His priorities    are... different from ours.
I understand, Brother.
No you don't, but you will.
I followed your instructions to    the letter.
Very good. Who do you want    eliminated?
It's not that kind of job.
Then why call an eliminator?
What's an eliminator?
Shh.        I'm putting together a little    rescue mission and I'd like you    to be part of my team.
I work alone.
You'll be paid in latinum.
I don't care about latinum.
You're right. His priorities are    different.
All right, forget the latinum.    I'm told you like an opportunity    to test your abilities.
I enjoy a challenge.
Then you should know this -- the    person we're going to rescue is    being held by the Dominion.
The Dominion?
Should be quite a challenge...
How the mighty have fallen.
Cousin Quark!
I hear you were arrested on Thalos    Six for vagrancy.

And it's all your fault. I was    a thriving weapons merchant until    I went into business with you.    You ruined me. If I ever get out    of here, cousin, I'll make you pay    for what you did to me.
Lower the forcefield.
Now... what is it, exactly, you're    going to do to me?
I don't understand.
Quark paid your fine. You're a    free man.
What do I have to do in return?
Earn some latinum.
Tell me more.
On the bar, you will find a PADD    with a schematic of a Dominion    internment center. You may now    examine the schematic.
How do we know these schematics   are accurate?
Sir.
No need to stand on formalities   here -- call me Leck.
No, I meant you should call me   "sir."
Don't be ridiculous.
You mean "don't be ridiculous,   sir."
Gentleman, please.       Let's not squabble. We're a team,   Nog.
"We're a team, sir."
Stay out of this.       Listen to me, Nog --
That's it, I quit.
You can't quit -- this isn't a   game.
How are we supposed to get to this   internment center anyway?
Do we have a ship?
We'll get one.
We don't have a ship?
I said we'll get one.
How?
We'll find one.
Where?
I don't know -- think of it as a   challenge.
Liquidator Brunt.
That's ex-liquidator Brunt.       Thanks to your brother, I'm no   longer with the Ferengi Commerce   Authority.
A child.       A moron.       A failure.       And a psychopath.
Quite a little team you've put   together...
What do you want, Brunt?
I'm here to sign up. I'm going   to help you rescue your mother.
How do you know about Moogie?
I know a lot of things.
You think if you help save my   mother, the Nagus will give you   your old job back.
When do we leave?
We're not leaving... not with you    anyway.
That's one thing we can all agree    on --
No one likes liquidators.
Or even ex-liquidators.
The team has spoken.
Besides, there's the twenty bar    reward to consider.
Better to split it five ways than    six.
Fine, I'll just get on my ship and    leave.
Did you say ship?
That's right... why?
Now we are six.
Don't move! You're surrounded.
Don't shoot -- I surrender!
No, no, no!
Computer -- freeze program. Reset   Jem'Hadar.
I think we're getting better.
No, you're not. This is the    eighth run-through and you haven't    been able to hit a single    Jem'Hadar.        And you shot Moogie.
I could see that we weren't going    to rescue her -- so I put her out    of her misery.
Who invited him along?
Maybe we should start off with    something easier.
Like what?
Like ambushing a couple of Bolians.
You couldn't ambush a Bolian if    he were blindfolded and tied to    a tree.
That's enough!
Get out -- all of you.
You heard me -- go.
But, Brother, don't you want to    keep practicing?
We're wasting our time, Rom. We    couldn't get anywhere near Moogie,    let alone rescue her.
I guess we're not cut out to be    heroes after all.

And to think... just a few short    days ago, I was sitting on top of    the world. The king of squill.    You should've been there, Brother.    It was a very delicate    negotiation. It could've gone    either way... but I took my time,    picked my moment, then went in for    the kill.

Brother -- we've been going about    this the wrong way. We're not    commandos, we're negotiators. We    make deals. That's what we're    good at. The Dominion has    something we want -- so we need    to find something they want.
And then we make a trade. That    way, everyone goes home happy.
Happy and alive. Now what do we    have to trade?
Captain, I can't thank you enough    for all your help.
Don't thank me -- thank Major    Kira. She's the one that    convinced me to talk to Starfleet    on your behalf.
Consider it payback, Quark. For    rescuing me from the Dominion.
Breaking you out of the station's    holding cell was one thing...
Every negotiation has its share    of danger, captain.
If you say so.
I guess it's time for me to pick    up my prisoner.
Just be careful not to turn your    back on him, Quark. He's not to    be trusted.
Neither am I.
Excuse me.
Sorry.
This isn't a ship, it's a closet.
You don't like it here? Leave.

I'll go.    (off their contemptuous    looks)   That way there'll be more room for   the rest of you. Besides, this   isn't a rescue mission anymore --   it's a simple prisoner exchange.   I don't know why Quark needs any   of us.
Because he doesn't trust the    Dominion... and neither do I.
Why would the Dominion pick a    deserted Cardassian space station    to make the trade?
They didn't pick it -- Quark did.    I've been there. It's the same    design as Deep Space Nine, so we    know the layout.
In that case, you have nothing to    worry about. There'll be plenty    of places for you to run and hide.
Good.
I mean... you know...       Coward!
Everyone, this is Keevan. We're    going to trade him for Ishka.
(all smiles, to the    Vorta)    Hi. I'm Rom.       This is Nog, that's Brunt --
Rom -- he doesn't care.
Truer words have never been    spoken. I advise you all to send    final messages to your loved ones    and make sure your wills are in    order.
Why?
Because the moment we leave this    station, you'll have signed your    death warrants.
Now, if you don't mind, I'm going    to take a nap.
All clear!
Are you sure?
The tricorder indicates no other    lifeforms on the station.
All right -- let's head for base    camp.
Base camp?
He means the Infirmary.       It's right over there.
Come on, let's move it. On the   double.
Two slips of latinum to the first   man who makes it to the Infirmary.
I mean base camp.
You don't pay soldiers to do their   duty.
You do if they're Ferengi.
Great, another closet.

We've chosen this spot for a    reason. For one thing, it's a    confined area with only two ways    in or out.        ... this one, and the one in there.    Secondly, it's near an airlock    which gives us access to our ship.    And thirdly, it's on the Promenade    where the prisoner exchange will    take place.        Don't touch that.
Some of this medical equipment is    still functioning.
Anything for an upset stomach?
What you need is a new backbone.
Hey, I'm a weapons dealer -- not    a soldier.
Cousin...
Sir, may I suggest we start    setting up our defense perimeter?
Good idea. How much is it going    to cost me?
Don't worry, no charge.

Starfleet has really corrupted    you, hasn't it? You can start by    getting the external sensors back    on-line. I want to know the    minute a Dominion ship comes    within ten million kilometers of    this station.
I'll set up a transport jamming    signal -- that way, the Dominion    won't be able to beam our prisoner    away without our say-so.
We certainly wouldn't want that    to happen, would we?
You don't sound too happy at the    thought of being reunited with    your people.
Believe me when I tell you I have    nothing to be happy about. Vorta    are supposed to commit suicide    when they're captured. I failed    to follow that rather... harsh    policy.
They're going to execute you?
After what is surely going to be    a most unpleasant debriefing.
I'm sorry to hear that, but it's    not my problem. All I want is my    Moogie back.
By the time the Dominion is done    with you, all you'll want is a    quick death.
Take him into the next room and    see that he stays there.
We'll post a guard on him at all    times. Four-hour shifts.
You heard him.        There's something you could    clarify for me -- what's the most    vulnerable part of a Jem'Hadar's    body?
All right, you have your orders.    Let's get to work.
My son the soldier.
They've ruined him.
What was that?
Who's screaming?
It's Gaila.
The Vorta -- where is he?
I don't know.
What do you mean you don't know?
You were guarding him.
He must've slipped away while I    was sleeping.
Sleeping? Who said you could    sleep?
I couldn't help it -- I was tired.    I couldn't get any rest on the    ship --
(realizing where Keevan     is headed)    The ship!
If Keevan gets away, we're    finished.
Going someplace?
Apparently not. I couldn't get    the impulse engines on-line.
That's because I had Rom disengage    the induction matrix.
Then why'd you bother chasing    me?
Because sometimes my brother gets    things wrong.
All right, everyone relax. No    harm done. We still have our    prisoner.
What's that?
It's the alarm I set up. It means    a Dominion ship is approaching.
To the Infirmary!
Now what?
Someone turned the alarm off.
It might've turned off by itself.
Do you hear something?
Someone's out there.
One of us should check -- to make   sure.       I nominate you.
Me?
I'll go.
Anybody there?
You could say that...
I wonder what they're doing out    there...
Shh.
I don't hear anything.
Quiet.
Why are we hiding?
There are Jem'Hadar out there.
Of course they're out there -- we    asked them to come.
He's right. Everything's going    according to plan. Now all you    have to do is negotiate the    prisoner exchange. Remember, be    firm, strong...
But don't get them angry.
Good luck, Brother. Say, "hi" to    Moogie for me.
What if it's a trap?
Of course it's a trap. They're    not here to negotiate -- they're    here to kill us all.
You think?
Don't listen to him. He's just    trying to save his own neck.
I'm trying to save all our necks.
Ferengi. Show yourself. We're    here to trade.
Don't go out there. We must get    back to the ship. Our only hope    is to escape.
We're not going anywhere. Not    without Moogie.        Right, uncle?
Right.
Ferengi. I don't like to be kept    waiting.
I'm coming, I'm coming.
And you two are coming with me.
I was afraid he was going to say   that...
Moooogie!
My boys... I knew you'd come.
You look beautiful.
My lobes haven't been this firm    in over a century.
I guess that makes this all    worthwhile.
Don't you start with me, Quark.
What a touching and heartfelt    reunion... I'm glad I was here to    witness it. Now... where is    Keevan? I wish to conclude this    transaction.
All in good time. First, I need    some... assurances.
What kind of assurances?
Well, for one thing -- I don't    want any Jem'Hadar soldiers on the    station.
That would leave me in a very    vulnerable position. One Vorta    against six Ferengi...
(re: Yelgrun's two    guards)   If it makes you feel better, these   two can stay.
I feel safer already. Now where's    Keevan?
Hold on, I'm not done yet. Then    you're going to tell your helmsman    to head back to Dominion    territory, warp nine.
That would leave me stranded    here...
For a few days.
I see. By the time they return,    you'll be long gone.
That's the idea.
On the other hand... I could just    have my Jem'Hadar storm the    Infirmary and kill you all.
I like our plan better.
You attack the Infirmary and    Keevan will be the first to die.
Keevan's fate has already been    sealed.
Maybe. But before he dies, I'll    bet you'll want to know what    Dominion secrets he revealed to    the Federation.
He's got you there, Yelgrun.
Your people have a reputation for    cunning. I see that it's well-   earned. Perhaps one day, the    Ferengi will take their place as    valued members of the Dominion.
Anything's possible.
I will begin evacuating the    Jem'Hadar at once.
We can exchange the prisoners    in... let's say, half an hour?
We'll be waiting.
One last thing... how do we know    that's really Moogie and not a    changeling?
I think that uniform is too tight    on you, Nog. It's cutting off    circulation to your brain.
Sounds like Moogie.
Only one way to find out...
Wait.        This should be... interesting.
Oww!
It's real blood all right.
I knew it was Moogie.
Now let's see if you're a   changeling...
Oww!
That's no way to tell if he's a   changeling.
You're right -- give me that knife.
I don't think so.
Family. You understand...
Not really. I was cloned.
No parents...       That explains a lot.
No parents, no sweetheart, no    investment portfolio...
And no patience. We'll meet back    here in half an hour. Don't be    late.
You heard him, Quark. Rom -- I'm    counting on you. Remember, your    Moogie loves you.
You should've seen my brother --    he was brilliant!
In a half hour we'll have Moogie    back and we can all go home.
Home... to the torrential rains    of Ferenginar.
You know what I miss most? The    rotting vegetation.
And the dampness.
Oh, to stand once more in those    rivers of muck.
I only wish I could be there with    you.
I can't believe it. We're    actually going to get the reward    money. Fifty bars of gold-pressed    latinum.
Fifty bars?        You said the reward was twenty.
That's what Rom said, twenty.
He said fifty.
I thought you said you didn't care    about latinum?
I don't, but I don't like being    cheated.
Everyone calm down.
Calm down -- when my dear cousin    is trying to cheat me?
I'm not trying to cheat anyone.
Then what about the other thirty    bars?
There are no other thirty bars --        Are there?
I... I... no... not really...
He's lying. They're in it    together.
You're not going to get away with    it, Quark.
I come here... risk my life... and    for what?
You've had this coming for a long    time, Cousin --
No!
Look out!
I hate Ferengi
What are we going to do? We can't    have a prisoner exchange without    a prisoner.
If they find out Keevan's dead...    they're going to kill us.
Would you stop saying that.
Maybe if we surrender, they won't    hurt us.
I've got a better idea -- we sneak    back to my ship and try to escape.
It's a big station... easy to get    lost in. If we hide, maybe they    won't find us.
No one's hiding, no one's    escaping, and no one's    surrendering! What's the matter    with you people? Have you    forgotten the Battle of Prexnak?
Who could forget the most    important battle in Ferengi    history?
Ten Ferengi stood alone against   two hundred and seventy-three    Lytasians.
As I recall, all ten Ferengi were    slaughtered.
The point is we Ferengi are just    as tough as anybody in the galaxy.    And this is our chance to prove    it once and for all.
Quark's right. Let's do it for    Ishka. Let's do it for the Grand    Nagus. Let's do it for Ferengis    everywhere --
Let's do it for an equal share of    fifty bars of gold-pressed latinum.
It always comes down to profit    with you people, doesn't it?
We're Ferengi.
And that's why I love you. Fifty    bars it is.        Minus my usual finder's fee.
Well, there's no doubt about it    According to these readings, this    man is dead.
Thank you, Doctor Nog.
I just wanted to be sure. I    thought maybe we could revive    him... but I guess not.
He's alive!
No, he isn't. It was just this    neural stimulator. It caused a    reflexive impulse in his    cerebellum.
I never knew you studied medicine    at the Academy.
I didn't. But if you think about    it, medicine isn't that different    from engineering... it's all about    keeping things running -- fixing    broken parts.
Are you thinking what I'm thinking?
Find me more neural stimulators.
It's time Ferengi. Bring out your    prisoner.
Stall them, Uncle.
I'll try.
I've done as you asked. The    Jem'Hadar are on their way back    to Dominion territory. We're    alone on the station.
Wonderful.
Now bring out Keevan and we can    conclude our business.
Keevan. Right, absolutely...
I'm waiting.
He'll be right out.        But first... my brother has to run    some sensor scans to make sure    that the Jem'Hadar have really    left.
That's unnecessary. The Jem'Hadar    are gone. Now bring me Keevan.
I will. In a few minutes.
No, not in a few minutes -- now.    Or perhaps you've changed your    mind and you don't want your    mother back.    (to the Jem'Hadar, re:     Ishka)    Kill her.
No!
Give them what they want, Quark.
I intend to.
Excellent.
As soon as my brother completes    his sensor scans.
And I thought the Breen were    annoying. Very well, five minutes.        But I will not tolerate any more    delays...
Neither will I.
That goes for me, too.        You see, we're all in agreement.
One more thing...
Why am I not surprised?
The prisoner exchange... I'd like it   to take place outside Airlock Three.
What's wrong with the Promenade?
Nothing. Except my ship is docked   at Airlock Three. You understand...
Only too well. But I must say,   your lack of trust saddens me.
A sign of the times.
Nog -- you've got five minutes.
Everyone step back.
Seventy-five hundred lots of    Hipecat futures?

The Hipecat root is very    versatile... it's used in certain    medicines, defractive optics, and    even some beauty supplies.        Here, feel how smooth my head is.    Cream of Hipecat... I apply it    twice a day. You see, a    diversified financial portfolio    can mean greater profits and    healthier-looking skin.
Fascinating.        I'd love to hear more, but if your    son doesn't show up soon, I'm    afraid I'm going to have to kill    you.
Yelgrun, you ready?
I've been ready for hours.
On the count of three, we release    our prisoners. Agreed?
Agreed.
One, two...
...three.
What have they done to him?
Straighten him out... straighten    him out.
I'm trying.
I hope you have a way to get us   out of here.
So do I.
Stop them!
Will you please turn him off.
I can't. The transceiver is    jammed.
Oh, Quark -- the Grand Nagus is    going to be so proud of you... I    know I am.
Moogie.
What do we do with this one?
We'll take him with us. He'll be    our gift to Starfleet. They gave    us a Vorta, we'll give them one    back.
Ferengi...
I know, I know -- you hate us.
All right you -- get moving.
I've never seen a sloppier, more    amateurish operation in my life...    If you ever do something like this    again -- count me in.
You'll be the first one I call.
If I even think about doing    something like this again... shoot    me.
So, Brother, how does it feel to    be a hero?
You tell me.
It feels...       ... good?
You bet it does.
